question: the set of rules that defines a correctly structured document in a language
a character or string incorrectly placed in a command or instruction that causes a failure in execution
a named storage location that can store changeable information, depending on conditions or on information passed to the program. A number, string, or boolean that can be set, changed, and recalled
a statement that sets a value to a named variable
the operator used to assign a new value to a variable. In Python, =
returns True if the value on the left is equal to the value on the right, otherwise it returns False. In Python, it is the characters ==
a mathematical character that takes two numbers and performs a calculation on them. For example, +
a floating-point decimal number. For example, 42.5, 0.001, or -3.729
changing the data type of a piece of data from one type to another

a named group of programming instructions that performs a specific task separately from a main script and returns to the main script when it is complete. Reusable abstractions that reduce the complexity of writing and maintaining programs.
a named block of code that includes the keyword def followed by a name, any arguments that are required, code inside the function, and an output that is returned
a request that runs the code inside of a function
a device, system or object which can be viewed in terms of its inputs and outputs
a keyword that tells the program to leave the function and send back a value
a value that is passed between programs, scripts or functions. Information sent to a function to customize it for a specific need.
statements that can be read in the code but do not affect the code in any way. In Python, they begin with a #
process of naming multi-word variables without spaces and so that words in the middle of the phrase begins with a capital letter. For example, numberOfCars, iPhone, eBay
the operation of joining character strings end-to-end. For example, 'snow' + 'man' is 'snowman'
what section of the code can use a variable, typically caused by where the variable was first created
a variable created inside a function definition, that cannot be used outside the function
